name: RiskEvidenceSynthesis
publisher: Health Level Seven International (Clinical Decision Support)
description: The RiskEvidenceSynthesis resource describes the likelihood of an outcome in a population plus exposure state where the risk estimate is derived from a combination of research studies.

element.short: A quantified estimate of risk based on a body of evidence
element.definition: The RiskEvidenceSynthesis resource describes the likelihood of an outcome in a population plus exposure state where the risk estimate is derived from a combination of research studies.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $id in f:contained/*/f:id/@value return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management
Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A human language.

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Canonical identifier for this risk evidence synthesis, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this risk evidence synthesis when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this risk evidence synthesis is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the risk evidence synthesis is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the risk evidence synthesis to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional identifier for the risk evidence synthesis
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this risk evidence synthesis when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this risk evidence synthesis outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Business version of the risk evidence synthesis
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the risk evidence synthesis when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the risk evidence synthesis author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different risk evidence synthesis instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the risk evidence synthesis with the format [url]|[version].

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this risk evidence synthesis (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the risk evidence synthesis. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this risk evidence synthesis (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the risk evidence synthesis.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The status of this risk evidence synthesis. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of risk evidence synthesiss that are appropriate for use versus not.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the risk evidence synthesis was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the risk evidence synthesis changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the risk evidence synthesis. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the risk evidence synthesis.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the risk evidence synthesis is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the risk evidence synthesis. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the risk evidence synthesis. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the risk evidence synthesis.  May also allow for contact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Natural language description of the risk evidence synthesis
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the risk evidence synthesis from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the risk evidence synthesis was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the risk evidence synthesis as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the risk evidence synthesis is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the risk evidence synthesis was created).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes
element.definition: A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate risk evidence synthesis instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for risk evidence synthesis (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the risk evidence synthesis is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the risk evidence synthesis to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the risk evidence synthesis and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the risk evidence synthesis.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the risk evidence synthesis and/or its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the risk evidence synthesis was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the risk evidence synthesis was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the risk evidence synthesis is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the risk evidence synthesis content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.comment: The effective period for a risk evidence synthesis  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the risk evidence synthesis are or are expected to be used instead.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The category of the EffectEvidenceSynthesis, such as Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc.
element.definition: Descriptive topics related to the content of the RiskEvidenceSynthesis. Topics provide a high-level categorization grouping types of EffectEvidenceSynthesiss that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the RiskEvidenceSynthesis so that it can be found by topical searches.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: High-level categorization of the definition, used for searching, sorting, and filtering.

element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: .participation[typeCode=VRF] {not clear whether VRF best corresponds to reviewer or endorser}

element.definition: An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: .participation[typeCode=VRF] {not clear whether VRF best corresponds to reviewer or endorser}

element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.
element.requirements: RiskEvidenceSynthesiss must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Type of synthesis eg meta-analysis.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Types of combining results from a body of evidence (eg. summary data meta-analysis).

element.definition: Type of study eg randomized trial.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Types of research studies (types of research methods).

element.definition: A reference to a EvidenceVariable resource that defines the population for the research.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A reference to a EvidenceVariable resource that defines the exposure for the research.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A reference to a EvidenceVariable resomece that defines the outcome for the research.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A description of the size of the sample involved in the synthesis.

The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Type of subcomponent of certainty rating
element.definition: Type of subcomponent of certainty rating.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The subcomponent classification of quality of evidence rating systems.

element.definition: A rating of a subcomponent of rating certainty.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The quality rating of the subcomponent of a quality of evidence rating.

element.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes
element.definition: A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A quantified estimate of risk based on a body of evidence
element.definition: The RiskEvidenceSynthesis resource describes the likelihood of an outcome in a population plus exposure state where the risk estimate is derived from a combination of research studies.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.short: Canonical identifier for this risk evidence synthesis, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this risk evidence synthesis when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this risk evidence synthesis is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the risk evidence synthesis is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the risk evidence synthesis to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the risk evidence synthesis
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this risk evidence synthesis when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this risk evidence synthesis outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the risk evidence synthesis
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the risk evidence synthesis when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the risk evidence synthesis author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different risk evidence synthesis instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the risk evidence synthesis with the format [url]|[version].

element.short: Name for this risk evidence synthesis (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the risk evidence synthesis. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this risk evidence synthesis (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the risk evidence synthesis.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.definition: The status of this risk evidence synthesis. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of risk evidence synthesiss that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the risk evidence synthesis was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the risk evidence synthesis changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the risk evidence synthesis. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the risk evidence synthesis.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the risk evidence synthesis is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the risk evidence synthesis. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the risk evidence synthesis. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the risk evidence synthesis.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.short: Natural language description of the risk evidence synthesis
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the risk evidence synthesis from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the risk evidence synthesis was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the risk evidence synthesis as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the risk evidence synthesis is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the risk evidence synthesis was created).

element.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes
element.definition: A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate risk evidence synthesis instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for risk evidence synthesis (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the risk evidence synthesis is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the risk evidence synthesis to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the risk evidence synthesis and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the risk evidence synthesis.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the risk evidence synthesis and/or its content.

element.short: When the risk evidence synthesis was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

element.short: When the risk evidence synthesis was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

element.short: When the risk evidence synthesis is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the risk evidence synthesis content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.comment: The effective period for a risk evidence synthesis  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the risk evidence synthesis are or are expected to be used instead.

element.short: The category of the EffectEvidenceSynthesis, such as Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc.
element.definition: Descriptive topics related to the content of the RiskEvidenceSynthesis. Topics provide a high-level categorization grouping types of EffectEvidenceSynthesiss that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the RiskEvidenceSynthesis so that it can be found by topical searches.

binding.description: High-level categorization of the definition, used for searching, sorting, and filtering.

element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.
An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.
An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.

mapping.map: .participation[typeCode=VRF] {not clear whether VRF best corresponds to reviewer or endorser}

element.definition: An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.

mapping.map: .participation[typeCode=VRF] {not clear whether VRF best corresponds to reviewer or endorser}

element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.
element.requirements: RiskEvidenceSynthesiss must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

element.definition: Type of synthesis eg meta-analysis.

binding.description: Types of combining results from a body of evidence (eg. summary data meta-analysis).

element.definition: Type of study eg randomized trial.

binding.description: Types of research studies (types of research methods).

element.definition: A reference to a EvidenceVariable resource that defines the population for the research.
A reference to a EvidenceVariable resource that defines the exposure for the research.
A reference to a EvidenceVariable resomece that defines the outcome for the research.
A description of the size of the sample involved in the synthesis.
Human-readable summary of sample size.
Number of studies included in this evidence synthesis.
Number of participants included in this evidence synthesis.
The estimated risk of the outcome.
Human-readable summary of risk estimate.
Examples include proportion and mean.

binding.description: Whether the risk estimate is dichotomous, continuous or qualitative and the specific type of risk estimate (eg proportion or median).

element.definition: The point estimate of the risk estimate.

element.short: What unit is the outcome described in?
element.definition: Specifies the UCUM unit for the outcome.

binding.description: Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM).

element.definition: The sample size for the group that was measured for this risk estimate.
The number of group members with the outcome of interest.
A description of the precision of the estimate for the effect.
Examples include confidence interval and interquartile range.

binding.description: Method of reporting variability of estimates, such as confidence intervals, interquartile range or standard deviation.

element.definition: Use 95 for a 95% confidence interval.
Lower bound of confidence interval.
Upper bound of confidence interval.
A description of the certainty of the risk estimate.
A rating of the certainty of the effect estimate.

binding.description: The quality of the evidence described. The code system used specifies the quality scale used to grade this evidence source while the code specifies the actual quality score (represented as a coded value) associated with the evidence.

element.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes
element.definition: A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.

element.short: A component that contributes to the overall certainty
element.definition: A description of a component of the overall certainty.

element.short: Type of subcomponent of certainty rating
element.definition: Type of subcomponent of certainty rating.

binding.description: The subcomponent classification of quality of evidence rating systems.

element.definition: A rating of a subcomponent of rating certainty.

binding.description: The quality rating of the subcomponent of a quality of evidence rating.

element.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes
element.definition: A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.
